elements.content: A porous polyhedral metal-organic framework has been constructed by utilizing Zn2(COO)4 and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as nodes and the flexible hexacarboxylate as linkers. The framework contains four types of interconnected polyhedral cages, rhombic dodecahedron, tetrahedron, octahedron, and distorted tetragonal prism. To identify the topology of the whole network, the four types of polyhedral cages can be viewed as nodes, and the whole network is signed as a (6,6,12,12) network. In another view of point, the Zn2(COO)3 SBU, Zn2(COO)4 SBU and hexacarboxylate ligands can also be considered as nodes, then the network is simply signed as a (3,4,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol (43) (4462) (4679).
elements.clean_text: A porous polyhedral metal-organic framework has been constructed by utilizing Zn2(COO)4 and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as nodes and the flexible hexacarboxylate as linkers. The framework contains four types of interconnected polyhedral cages, rhombic dodecahedron, tetrahedron, octahedron, and distorted tetragonal prism. To identify the topology of the whole network, the four types of polyhedral cages can be viewed as nodes, and the whole network is signed as a (6,6,12,12) network. In another view of point, the Zn2(COO)3 SBU, Zn2(COO)4 SBU and hexacarboxylate ligands can also be considered as nodes, then the network is simply signed as a (3,4,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol (43) (4462) (4679).

elements.content: A porous polyhedral metal-organic framework containing four types of interconnected tetrahedral, octahedral, tetragonal, and dodecahedral cages has been constructed by utilizing Zn2(COO)4 and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as nodes and flexible hexacarboxylate as linkers.
elements.clean_text: A porous polyhedral metal-organic framework containing four types of interconnected tetrahedral, octahedral, tetragonal, and dodecahedral cages has been constructed by utilizing Zn2(COO)4 and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as nodes and flexible hexacarboxylate as linkers.

elements.content: Recently, porous polyhedral metal-organic frameworks (PPMOFs) have been extensively studied because of their potential application for selective gas storage. In contrast to the conventional open-channel-type porous metal-organic frameworks (PMOFs), these PPMOFs hold large ordered cavities. Up to now, several kinds of polyhedra such as trigonal bipyramids, hexagonal bipyramids, truncated tetrahedra, truncated octahedra, truncated cuboctahedra, cuboctahedra, small rhombihexahedron, cubohemioctahedra, rhombicuboctahendra, and octahedra have been reported. To synthesize these new materials, the selection of appropriate organic linkers with given shape and function would be a crucial step. The C 3-symmetry ligands, such as 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and its analogues, have been demonstrated to be efficient skeletons to construct PPMOFs for their good directionality and rigidity. By using these coplanar or uncoplanar robust triangular ligands, researchers have synthesized a series of notable PPMOFs. Compared with these rigid ligands, flexible trigonal ligands with multiple conformations will endow the assembly systems with structural diversity and more intriguing topologies as well as properties. For example, we have reported a discrete O h -symmetry nanocage and a polymeric chain containing nanotunnels based on a trimonodentate N-donor ligand. However, there are no examples of PPMOFs built from flexible C 3-symmetry organic linkers. Herein, we wish to report a noninterpenetrated PPMOF derived from a flexible hexacarboxylate linker, which consists of four kinds of polyhedral cages−rhombic dodecahedron, tetrahedron, octahedron, and distorted tetragonal prism (see the , Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: Recently, porous polyhedral metal-organic frameworks (PPMOFs) have been extensively studied because of their potential application for selective gas storage. In contrast to the conventional open-channel-type porous metal-organic frameworks (PMOFs), these PPMOFs hold large ordered cavities. Up to now, several kinds of polyhedra such as trigonal bipyramids, hexagonal bipyramids, truncated tetrahedra, truncated octahedra, truncated cuboctahedra, cuboctahedra, small rhombihexahedron, cubohemioctahedra, rhombicuboctahendra, and octahedra have been reported. To synthesize these new materials, the selection of appropriate organic linkers with given shape and function would be a crucial step. The C 3-symmetry ligands, such as 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and its analogues, have been demonstrated to be efficient skeletons to construct PPMOFs for their good directionality and rigidity. By using these coplanar or uncoplanar robust triangular ligands, researchers have synthesized a series of notable PPMOFs.  Compared with these rigid ligands, flexible trigonal ligands with multiple conformations will endow the assembly systems with structural diversity and more intriguing topologies as well as properties. For example, we have reported a discrete O  h -symmetry nanocage and a polymeric chain containing nanotunnels based on a trimonodentate N-donor ligand. However, there are no examples of PPMOFs built from flexible C 3-symmetry organic linkers. Herein, we wish to report a noninterpenetrated PPMOF derived from a flexible hexacarboxylate linker, which consists of four kinds of polyhedral cages-rhombic dodecahedron, tetrahedron, octahedron, and distorted tetragonal prism (see the , Figure S1).

elements.content: The flexible hexacarboxylate ligand, 5,5′,5′′-(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl) trismethylene-trisoxy-triisophthalic acid (H 6 L, C36H30O15), is our choice for constructing PPMOFs. This tritopic ligand possesses three 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) units, which are well-known for the construction of metal-organic cuboctahedra. Three −CH2−O− spacers, which link the bdc units to the central benzene ring, endow the whole ligand certain flexibility. Crystals of [Zn7 L 2(OH)2(H2O)9]·12.25H2O (1) were obtained via self-assembly of Zn(NO3)2 and H 6 L via the solvothermal reaction. In complex 1, ligand L adopts a syn, syn, syn conformation so that three bdc groups are at the same side of the central phenyl ring (Figure ). Unlike the recently reported robust hexacarboxylate ligand, the three peripheral benzene rings holding the carboxyl functional groups here in L are perpendicular to the central ring rather than coplanar (Figure a). Of the two carboxylic groups in each bdc unit, one participates in the formation of Zn2(COO)4 SBU and the other in the formation of Zn2(COO)3 SBU (SBU = secondary building unit, structures b and c in Figure ). Although four-connected paddle-wheel-like M2(COO)4 SBUs are extensively applied in the syntheses of various MOFs, three-connected triangular M2(COO)3 SBUs are rarely seen. To the best of our knowledge, there have not been examples of the coexistence of these two different nodes before.
elements.clean_text: The flexible hexacarboxylate ligand, 5,5',5''-(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl) trismethylene-trisoxy-triisophthalic acid (H  6  L, C36H30O15), is our choice for constructing PPMOFs. This tritopic ligand possesses three 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) units, which are well-known for the construction of metal-organic cuboctahedra. Three -CH2-O- spacers, which link the bdc units to the central benzene ring, endow the whole ligand certain flexibility. Crystals of [Zn7 L 2(OH)2(H2O)9]⋅12.25H2O (1) were obtained via self-assembly of Zn(NO3)2 and H  6  L via the solvothermal reaction. In complex 1, ligand L adopts a syn, syn, syn conformation so that three bdc groups are at the same side of the central phenyl ring (Figure ). Unlike the recently reported robust hexacarboxylate ligand, the three peripheral benzene rings holding the carboxyl functional groups here in L are perpendicular to the central ring rather than coplanar (Figure a). Of the two carboxylic groups in each bdc unit, one participates in the formation of Zn2(COO)4 SBU and the other in the formation of Zn2(COO)3 SBU (SBU = secondary building unit, structures b and c in Figure ). Although four-connected paddle-wheel-like M2(COO)4 SBUs are extensively applied in the syntheses of various MOFs, three-connected triangular M2(COO)3 SBUs are rarely seen. To the best of our knowledge, there have not been examples of the coexistence of these two different nodes before.

elements.content: Molecular structure of 1 determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction: (a) conformation of ligand L; (b) two different kinds of metal nodes, Zn2(COO)3 SBU and Zn2(COO)4 SBU; (c) coordination environment of ligandL.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of 1 determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction: (a) conformation of ligand L; (b) two different kinds of metal nodes, Zn2(COO)3 SBU and Zn2(COO)4 SBU; (c) coordination environment of ligandL.

elements.content: First, six Zn2(COO)4 SBUs as four-connected vertexes and eight Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as three-connected vertexes form a rarely seen rhombic dodecahedron (RD), where forty-eight bdc units are used for the edges (Figure ). The rhombic window, which contains a pair of the Zn2(COO)4 SBUs and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as vertexes, is slightly distorted so that the four vertexes are not completely coplanar (Figure ). The interior cavity of the RD can be accessed via the centroid···centroid distances between the poly metallic vertexes along the C 3 or C 4 axis, which are 20.66 Å between two Zn2(COO)3 SBUs and 20.47 Å between two Zn2(COO)4 SBUs. According to the paper of O’Keeffe and Yaghi, there are three types of extreme configurations to form the RDs, in which the calculated extending angle of three-connected SBU η1 and four-connected SBU η2 should be (a) η1 = 120°, η2 = 48.2°, or (b) η1 = 109.5°, η2 = 70.5°, or (c) η1 = 60°, η2 = 90°. Corresponding examples of the type a and type c have been reported by Atwood and Long, but no examples of type b has been reported. In complex 1, if we do not take the angle of the bdc linker into account and consider the organic linker as a linear space, at this moment the η1 and η2 are 99.91 and 78.28°, respectively, which slightly deviate from the calculated values of type b (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: First, six Zn2(COO)4 SBUs as four-connected vertexes and eight Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as three-connected vertexes form a rarely seen rhombic dodecahedron (RD), where forty-eight bdc units are used for the edges (Figure ). The rhombic window, which contains a pair of the Zn2(COO)4 SBUs and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as vertexes, is slightly distorted so that the four vertexes are not completely coplanar (Figure ). The interior cavity of the RD can be accessed via the centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distances between the poly metallic vertexes along the C 3 or C 4 axis, which are 20.66 Å between two Zn2(COO)3 SBUs and 20.47 Å between two Zn2(COO)4 SBUs. According to the paper of O'Keeffe and Yaghi, there are three types of extreme configurations to form the RDs, in which the calculated extending angle of three-connected SBU η1 and four-connected SBU η2 should be (a) η1 = 120°, η2 = 48.2°, or (b) η1 = 109.5°, η2 = 70.5°, or (c) η1 = 60°, η2 = 90°. Corresponding examples of the type a and type c have been reported by Atwood and Long, but no examples of type b has been reported. In complex 1, if we do not take the angle of the bdc linker into account and consider the organic linker as a linear space, at this moment the η1 and η2 are 99.91 and 78.28°, respectively, which slightly deviate from the calculated values of type b (Figure ).

elements.content: Left: Rhombic dodecahedron in complex 1. The triangular Zn2(COO)3 SBUs are simplified as the blue nodes and the paddlewheel-like Zn2(COO)4 SBUs are simplified as the red nodes. Right: Rhombic window in the rhombic dodecahedron.
elements.clean_text: 2  Left: Rhombic dodecahedron in complex 1. The triangular Zn2(COO)3 SBUs are simplified as the blue nodes and the paddlewheel-like Zn2(COO)4 SBUs are simplified as the red nodes. Right: Rhombic window in the rhombic dodecahedron.

elements.content: The RD is interconnected to twelve identical polyhedral cages through its twelve rhombic windows (Figure a). If we consider the Zn2(COO)3 SBUs and Zn2(COO)4 SBUs as the vertexes of the polyhedron, this cage is a distorted tetragonal prism (DTP). The two rhombic basal faces are linked by four organic bdc−CH2−O−Ph−O−CH2−bdc spacers, which are across the four side faces of the DTP, respectively. Each bdc−CH2−O−Ph−O−CH2−bdc spacer acts as a tetratopic ligand and links one Zn2(COO)3 SBU and one Zn2(COO)4 SBU at each basal side. The centroid···centroid distance between the Zn2(COO)4 SBUs in the two basal faces is 16.37 Å and that between the Zn2(COO)3 SBUs is 13.98 Å (see structures b and c in Figure ), from which we can estimate the distance between the two basal planes. Additionally, this DTP has two kinds of different tetragonal windows at its sides, which are built from a pair of Zn2(COO)3 SBUs or Zn2(COO)4 SBUs with two bdc−CH2−O-Ph−O−CH2−bdc spacers, respectively. The window based on Zn2(COO)3 SBUs (10.86 × 9.14 Å, see Figure c) is slightly larger than that on Zn2(COO)4 SBUs (10.86 × 7.67 Å, see Figure b), which mainly results from the different coordination figurations of these two kinds of cluster nodes.
elements.clean_text: The RD is interconnected to twelve identical polyhedral cages through its twelve rhombic windows (Figure a). If we consider the Zn2(COO)3 SBUs and Zn2(COO)4 SBUs as the vertexes of the polyhedron, this cage is a distorted tetragonal prism (DTP). The two rhombic basal faces are linked by four organic bdc-CH2-O-Ph-O-CH2-bdc spacers, which are across the four side faces of the DTP, respectively. Each bdc-CH2-O-Ph-O-CH2-bdc spacer acts as a tetratopic ligand and links one Zn2(COO)3 SBU and one Zn2(COO)4 SBU at each basal side. The centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distance between the Zn2(COO)4 SBUs in the two basal faces is 16.37 Å and that between the Zn2(COO)3 SBUs is 13.98 Å (see structures b and c in Figure ), from which we can estimate the distance between the two basal planes. Additionally, this DTP has two kinds of different tetragonal windows at its sides, which are built from a pair of Zn2(COO)3 SBUs or Zn2(COO)4 SBUs with two bdc-CH2-O-Ph-O-CH2-bdc spacers, respectively. The window based on Zn2(COO)3 SBUs (10.86 × 9.14 Å, see Figure c) is slightly larger than that on Zn2(COO)4 SBUs (10.86 × 7.67 Å, see Figure b), which mainly results from the different coordination figurations of these two kinds of cluster nodes.

elements.content: (a) Distorted tetragonal prism in 1. The triangular Zn2(COO)3 SBUs are simplified as the blue nodes and the paddlewheel-like Zn2(COO)4 SBUs are simplified as the red nodes. (b) Side window constructed from two Zn2(COO)4 SBUs. (c) Side window constructed from two Zn2(COO)3 SBUs.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Distorted tetragonal prism in 1. The triangular Zn2(COO)3 SBUs are simplified as the blue nodes and the paddlewheel-like Zn2(COO)4 SBUs are simplified as the red nodes. (b) Side window constructed from two Zn2(COO)4 SBUs. (c) Side window constructed from two Zn2(COO)3 SBUs.

elements.content: Besides linking two RDs, this DTP also connects other two different kinds of polyhedral cages through its two kinds of lateral windows. First, through the window formed from Zn2(COO)3 SBUs, it connects one tetrahedral cage (TC) (Figure a). For ligand H 6 L, if omitting the three carboxyl groups forming Zn2(COO)4 SBUs, we can obtain a new C 3-symmetric ligand H 3 L † . In this cage, four Zn2(COO)3 SBUs locate on the corners of the tetrahedron. Four organic L † linkers, which each coordinates to three vertexes, cap the four triangular faces, respectively. The examples of such face-directed M4L4 tetrahedron have been reported by Albrecht and Raymond, in which the tetrahedrons are often closed rather than open. The most likely reason is that the rigid triangular ligands usually are nearly coplanar and have an angle of 120°, so that the potential windows are blocked by the groups of the ligands. However, in our tetrahedron, the flexible L † linker sustains the skeleton with the angle of 90°, which effectively separates two adjacent ligands and results in six large square windows (9.99 Å × 9.99 Å, see Figures c and a). From another point of view, if we consider the triangular L † linker as another kind of three-connected node, a heterocube (HC) can be obtained, in which L † extends itself along three perpendicular edges. Certainly, this cubic cage acts as a six-connected node to interconnect six DTPs through its six lateral faces.
elements.clean_text: Besides linking two RDs, this DTP also connects other two different kinds of polyhedral cages through its two kinds of lateral windows. First, through the window formed from Zn2(COO)3 SBUs, it connects one tetrahedral cage (TC) (Figure a). For ligand H  6  L, if omitting the three carboxyl groups forming Zn2(COO)4 SBUs, we can obtain a new C 3-symmetric ligand H  3  L  † . In this cage, four Zn2(COO)3 SBUs locate on the corners of the tetrahedron. Four organic L  †  linkers, which each coordinates to three vertexes, cap the four triangular faces, respectively. The examples of such face-directed M4L4 tetrahedron have been reported by Albrecht and Raymond, in which the tetrahedrons are often closed rather than open. The most likely reason is that the rigid triangular ligands usually are nearly coplanar and have an angle of 120°, so that the potential windows are blocked by the groups of the ligands. However, in our tetrahedron, the flexible L  †  linker sustains the skeleton with the angle of 90°, which effectively separates two adjacent ligands and results in six large square windows (9.99 Å × 9.99 Å, see Figures c and a). From another point of view, if we consider the triangular L  †  linker as another kind of three-connected node, a heterocube (HC) can be obtained, in which L  †  extends itself along three perpendicular edges. Certainly, this cubic cage acts as a six-connected node to interconnect six DTPs through its six lateral faces.

elements.content: (a) Relative positions of the tetrahedron (in blue solid lines) and the cube (in dashed two-colored lines) in tetrahedral cage. (b) Relative positions of the octahedron (in red solid lines) and the rhombic dodecahedron (in dashed two-colored lines) in octahedral cage.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Relative positions of the tetrahedron (in blue solid lines) and the cube (in dashed two-colored lines) in tetrahedral cage. (b) Relative positions of the octahedron (in red solid lines) and the rhombic dodecahedron (in dashed two-colored lines) in octahedral cage.

elements.content: The other two lateral windows constructed from Zn2(COO)4 SBUs in DTP are interconnected to two O h -symmetry M6L8 octahedral cages (OCs) respectively (See Figure b), which are similar to the one we reported before. Again, if we omit the three carboxyl groups forming Zn2(COO)3 SBUs in the H 6 L, a new triangular ligand H 3 L ‡ can be obtained. This face-directed truncated octahedral nanocage is constructed from six C 4-symmetric Zn2(COO)4 SBUs as the corners with eight C 3-symmetric L ‡ organic linkers spanning the triangular faces. If we regard the ligand L ‡ as a three-connected node, this octahedral cage can also be considered as a rhombic dodecahedron. Undoubtedly, this OC acts as a 12-connected node to interconnect 12 DTCs.
elements.clean_text: The other two lateral windows constructed from Zn2(COO)4 SBUs in DTP are interconnected to two O  h -symmetry M6L8 octahedral cages (OCs) respectively (See Figure b), which are similar to the one we reported before. Again, if we omit the three carboxyl groups forming Zn2(COO)3 SBUs in the H  6  L, a new triangular ligand H  3  L  ‡  can be obtained. This face-directed truncated octahedral nanocage is constructed from six C 4-symmetric Zn2(COO)4 SBUs as the corners with eight C 3-symmetric L  ‡  organic linkers spanning the triangular faces. If we regard the ligand L  ‡  as a three-connected node, this octahedral cage can also be considered as a rhombic dodecahedron. Undoubtedly, this OC acts as a 12-connected node to interconnect 12 DTCs.

elements.content: To identify the topology of the whole network, if we look the DTC, HC, RD, and OC as a six-connected node, a six-connected node, a 12-connected node and a 12-connected node respectively, the whole network arising from these four different polyhedral cages can be signed as a (6,6,12,12) network (see the , Figure S2). From another point of view, we can consider the Zn2(COO)3 SBU as a planar three-coordinate node and Zn2(COO)4 SBU as a planar four-coordinate node. Additionally, if we look at the flexible ligand L as a nonplanar six-connected node, we can simplify the network as a (3,4,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol (43) (44 62) (46 79).
elements.clean_text: To identify the topology of the whole network, if we look the DTC, HC, RD, and OC as a six-connected node, a six-connected node, a 12-connected node and a 12-connected node respectively, the whole network arising from these four different polyhedral cages can be signed as a (6,6,12,12) network (see the , Figure S2). From another point of view, we can consider the Zn2(COO)3 SBU as a planar three-coordinate node and Zn2(COO)4 SBU as a planar four-coordinate node. Additionally, if we look at the flexible ligand L as a nonplanar six-connected node, we can simplify the network as a (3,4,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol (43) (44 62) (46 79).

elements.content: In conclusion, we report a rarely seen PPMOF derived from a flexible C 3-symmetry organic ligand. Utilizing Zn2(COO)4 and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as nodes, the organic linkers form four types of interconnected polyhedral cages. Although usually the flexible ligands are inclined to give interpenetrated frames, especially for the existence of large voids, complex 1 is a noninterpenetrating 3D porous network. The most likely reason for 1 may be that the relatively small windows that interconnect the polyhedral cages prevent the interpenetration of the relatively large organic groups. We believe that this strategy may have general application in the search for the syntheses of porous materials. Future investigation will focus on the properties of 1 and is now in process.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we report a rarely seen PPMOF derived from a flexible C 3-symmetry organic ligand. Utilizing Zn2(COO)4 and Zn2(COO)3 SBUs as nodes, the organic linkers form four types of interconnected polyhedral cages. Although usually the flexible ligands are inclined to give interpenetrated frames, especially for the existence of large voids, complex 1 is a noninterpenetrating 3D porous network. The most likely reason for 1 may be that the relatively small windows that interconnect the polyhedral cages prevent the interpenetration of the relatively large organic groups. We believe that this strategy may have general application in the search for the syntheses of porous materials. Future investigation will focus on the properties of 1 and is now in process.

metadata.title:
A Porous Polyhedral Metal-Organic Framework Based on Zn2(COO)3 and Zn2(COO)4 SBUs
Communications
